Award.AwardTitle: Travel Grants for Presentations by Undergraduates at National Meetings
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds travel for undergraduate students to present their reserach at the annual winter Joint Mathematics Meetings (JMM) and Mathematical Association of America (MAA) summer MathFest meeting for a five-year period beginning in 2014. In 2014, the JMM will be held in Baltimore, MD from January 15 - January 18, and the MathFest meeting will be held in Portland, OR from August 7 - August 9. A dramatic increase in the number of undergraduates participating in research in mathematics has occurred over the past twenty-five years. Consequently, contributed talks and poster presentations by undergraduates have become an integral part of the MAA summer MathFest and the winter JMM, organized by the MAA and the American Mathematical Society. Participation in such settings offers undergraduates the opportunity to become part of the mathematical community at a national level while interacting with both practicing mathematicians and peers. Learning new mathematics and sharing experiences with others can provide strong motivation for continued study of mathematics. Despite the positive effects of the experience, lack of travel funding remains a significant barrier to participation in national meetings for many students, particularly at institutions with large populations of underrepresented students. The proposed project will provide travel grants to nearly 1400 undergraduates over a five-year period, affording them the opportunity to present their work at MAA MathFest or the JMM, with priority in funding given to students from underrepresented groups and institutions with less funding.

The value of involving undergraduates in research is well documented and the potential benefits are numerous. Indeed, a growing body of literature suggests that participation in undergraduate research increases retention rates and student engagement and is beneficial for students from many backgrounds. Moreover, several studies have indicated that students who participate in undergraduate research are significantly more likely to attend graduate school than those who do not. Research has also shown, however, that the communication of results through oral or written presentations is an essential feature of an effective undergraduate research experience. The MAA, with its focus on advancing mathematics at the undergraduate level, provides a mathematically rich and diverse program at its annual meetings, making the JMM and MAA MathFest ideal venues for undergraduates to disseminate their research results while interacting with both peers who are similarly engaged in research and practicing mathematicians. The experience of participating in a national meeting, particularly the largest annual mathematics meeting in the world (JMM) and the largest summertime annual gathering of mathematicians (MAA MathFest), can help students identify with becoming a professional mathematician and may motivate them to continue the study of mathematics. The proposed project will support increased engagement with mathematics and is expected to ultimately increase the number of students who pursue graduate studies in the mathematical sciences. Project results will be widely disseminated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to help develop the culture of research as a central part of the undergraduate experience for mathematics majors, from initial research to national presentation. Participation in a national meeting offers students the opportunity to become part of the mathematical community at a national level and interact with peers from other institutions. Specifically, this project expects to provide travel support to more than 1,300 undergraduate students from across the United States to present their mathematics research at a national conference (the winter JMM or summer MathFest).

The Joint Mathematics Meetings (JMM) of the American Mathematical Society (AMS) and the Mathematical Association of America (MAA) is held annually in January in varying locations across the United States. During the grant funding period (2014 – 2019), the JMM had between 6,000 and 6,500 attendees and featured presentations on a wide range of topics in mathematics and mathematics education. Meeting locations included Baltimore, San Antonio, Seattle, Atlanta, and San Diego. The JMM afforded mathematics undergraduates, many of whom were partially funded by this project, numerous opportunities to present their research via either an oral presentation or a poster, as well as a variety of other student-focused sessions, panels, workshops, and social events.

Likewise, MathFest, the annual summer meeting of the Mathematical Association of America, is held in August and offers a rich program suitable for university faculty, high school teachers, graduate and undergraduate students. With approximately 1,700 participants attending MathFest 2018 and around 30 student paper sessions featured annually, this venue serves as an alternative attractive opportunity for undergraduates to present their results. Undergraduates received partial travel support to present research results at MathFest in Portland, Washington, D.C., Columbus, Chicago, and Denver over the life of the grant cycle.

During the grant term, MAA awarded $695,798 (87% of its total grant amount) to a total of 1,941 students to attend and present at the JMM and/or MathFest conferences in January and July respectively. This includes grant funds used during our no-cost extension to support college women to attend the 2019 MathFest Mentoring Workshop.  This workshop provided information for undergraduate women interested in advanced study in mathematics, including graduate study in mathematics, careers available to women with an advanced mathematics degree, and constructing a life as a mathematician. The average award per student was $360.

As agreed with the NSF Program Officer when funding was approved, the funding priorities were as follows:

  1. Funding students from underrepresented groups (first priority: Hispanic/Latino, Black/African American, Native American, and Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander students; second priority: female students)
  2. Funding students from institutions with fewer resources and/or research opportunities (e.g. students from HBCUs and HSIs, institutions from ESPCoR states, PUIs above research institutions)

This project has enabled undergraduates to disseminate their research results at a national conference, as well as to learn new mathematics and be exposed to experts in their field that should further enhance their research. Additionally, presenting at a professional meeting can often be the first step towards publication; solo authored papers by undergraduates are appearing in lead professional society journals in increasing numbers (Gallian 2006).
